Award.AwardTitle: NeTs: Small: Collaborative Research: Inter-provider dynamics in neutral and non-neutral networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past five years, the network neutrality debate involving for-profit ISPs and "content" providers, together with security-related issues, has figured most prominently in the Western media's coverage of the Internet and in government regulatory hearings in both North America and Europe. The two principal issues have to do with equitable treatment of applications (application neutrality) and side payments between independent content and service providers.

The four research thrusts of this grant are: the development of unbiased, parsimonious models of macro-economic and networking dynamics of all parties involved; analyzing these models with an aim to assess the relative benefit of different pricing regimes, provider alliances, and service-differentiation strategies; acquiring current, real-world data and practical lessons-learned to inform these models; and focusing in particular on comparing neutral to non-neutral frameworks.

In a preliminary example study, a passive model of end-user demand was used to define a game between multiple ISPs and multiple content providers. The users could engage in two types of applications: one delay sensitive, the other throughput sensitive. The fraction of users engaged with a particular provider depended on the provider?s current prices, subject to a customer inertia model when competitors? prices were close. A regulated side-payment between providers of different types was considered. A surprising finding at stable Nash equilibrium was that monopolistic providers (say a single ISP) receiving side payments actually had less income than the 'neutral' scenario without side-payments (side payments result in increased end-user prices by the payee which lowers end-user demand). Revenues from the application types which consumed the most bandwidth were naturally affected the most.

The primary intellectual merit of this research has to do with the challenge of formulating tractable though realistic mathematical models of the cross-disciplinary elements of the macroscopic interactions among different entities participating in the Internet economy. Identified near-optimal strategies are tracked in the presence of naturally time-varying system parameters. Though a model may be simple, it often yields unexpectedly complex behavior (e.g., multiple Nash equilibria with differing stability qualities). Important real-world data and practical lessons will be identified in this research through the study of sensitivity of derived results to the different model parameters in play.

One aspect of the broader impact of this research pertains to the enormous financial stakes involved in the network neutrality debate, and therefore the potential of this research to influence significantly Internet operations and architectural development even in the near term. Industry outreach is a significant part of this research, not only to keep abreast of current developments, but also to obtain first-hand relevant data that hopefully can be disseminated to the broader research community. Another aspect of the broader impact of this research is the development and dissemination of related "economics" teaching modules suitable for networking graduate courses, and the recruitment and training of students from under-represented minority groups in Computer Science and Electrical and Computer Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For almost a decade, network neutrality has been actively debated. The issue is fundamentally related to anti-trust, i.e., the promotion of fair competition in the Internet marketplace and resulting in greater choice and lower cost to the consumers. Specifically, network neutrality spans application neutrality (an access provider cannot discriminate traffic based on type and origin) and does not allow (direct) side payments from remote, second-party content/service providers to access providers. The discussion in the lay media is often naive, e.g., confusing neutrality with free speech - Interent access and content/service provision over the Internet both typically involve for-profit businesses in the United States, and the Internet supports extremely important business-to-business interaction in addtion to public-commodity services. Moreover, the service level agreements (SLAs) at tier-1 ties have a significant impact on the Internet marketplace and on neutrality issues (i.e., asymmetries in total traffic volumes exchanged are "neutral" quantities on which payments may be based), something which is rarely mentioned in articles on neutrality in the lay media.

In the research activity supported by this grant, we typically developed a mathematical model of the network system to attempt to capture the different issues under consideration, including models of provider competition (consumer demand response) and possible regulated side payments between them. At a Nash or Stackelberg equilibrium for a given model, we attempt to show the impact of the regulator's decisions on the market according to different criteria including costs to the consumers and fair (neutral) treatment of the market participants. As there is often very little detailed, realistic data from industry to leverage (such data is typically very secretly held), our aim is to develop and analyze parsimonous models with as few parameters as possible.

With my UPenn collaborator, S. Sarkar,  and her student, M.H. Lotfi, we worked on an interesting competition model for celllular wireless access which also considered  modeling of differential service qualities. We studied the impact of side-payments on its complex equilibrium and found cases where a "non-neutral" scenario (with side-payments form content to access providers) would be more beneficial to consumers.

We also worked with Al Daoud & Liebeherr on a new and somewhat unusual model of cellular wireless access using the prisoner's dilemma framework. . In this model, secondary and primary access providers were involved, where the former lease spectrum from the latter.

With our collaborators at UMPC Paris (S. Fdida et al.), we considered neutrality in the context of proposed future Information Centric Networks (ICN). Here side payments from access providers to content/service providers may make sense as the former take an active role in determining the latter (based on their end-users' requests). 

We also explored some foundational issues associated with our main research thrusts including how altruistic (UPMC) and selfish (Jin & Wang, Pang) behavior by market participants (particularly consumers) complicate our game-theoretic models.

Finally, this project supported work with Jin & Wang on an paper on game-theoretic models of technology deployment.

A list of publications of this supported research can be found at this project's web site, http://www.cse.psu.edu/~gik2/1116626.html
